MELISSA FRANCIS, FOX NEWS HOST: Amazing. EVENING EDIT starts right now.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN BOLTON, UNITED STATES NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISOR: We're intending to put unprecedented pressure on Iran. Their currency is going through the floor, much of that in the past 90 days.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Trump appears to be threatening any country that does business with Iran by blowing up the Iran deal.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: In the spring, we lost the support we had, which was hard to achieve from Russia and China, and obviously the E.U.

BOLTON: Why do you want to do business with the world's largest financier of international terrorism? Really, the central bank of international terrorism. Do your shareholders feel good that you are doing business with a terrorist regime, that's the sort of thing I think everybody needs to ask.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX NEWS HOST: And the pressure is now on. President Trump warning European countries -- companies, you do business with Iran, you will not be doing business with the United States.

Now look at this. German carmaker Daimler did changed its expansion plans in Iran. So who is next to fall in line? We've got the names coming up. And you will not believe which European country is now stepping up.

And Iran's President Hassan Rouhani saying Iran cannot negotiate with U.S. while under sanctions. Accusing the U.S. of, quote, "psychological warfare." We debate that.

And coming up too, the latest on conservatives getting assaulted in public.

And also this, Tesla stock halted in trading today after billionaire, speaking of Elon Musk, he tweeted out that he may take Tesla's private. It was a tweet heard around the world. We've got the latest on that, and also Disney earnings and more.

Well, thank you so much for joining us. Thank you for watching. Money, politics, we've got the debate behind tomorrow's headlines. I'm Elizabeth MacDonald. THE EVENING EDIT starts right now.

All right. Let's get right to your money. Look at this. The Dow finishing up 126 points to 25,628. It's sleepy August, the Dow continues to go up. The S&P climbing to less than 1 percent from a new record. Tesla and Amazon on the move. More on your money in just a second.

But first, President Trump sanctions on Iran went into effect today, and businesses from Berlin, Paris, Rome to London now feeling pressure to back off from doing business in Iran.

And Germany is the country now stepping up and reportedly moving to stop the transfer of nearly $400 million in cash out of Germany to the Iranian regime. Iran wants its money. They want that 400 million now. To avoid that money being detained under looming sanctions.

While U.S. sanctions were also causing German auto giant Daimler, the maker of Mercedes, to abandon their expansion plans in Iran. Look at this. The maker of Peugeot cars, also the French oil company Total, and Germany's Siemens have also backed off.

A U.S. official now says nearly 100 international firms have announced they intend to leave Iran. Republican Senator Lindsey Graham also calling out to European companies saying it is time to make a choice.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: What is it about the ayatollah that you like? Why do you stand with him and against the people he is oppressing? Why do you want to give a man more money who's taken the money you've already given him to build the war machine to dismember the Mideast.

Do you think he is kidding when he says death to Israel? To the Europeans, you need to get with the Iranian people, and get behind Trump to break this regime's back before it is too late.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Joining me now, we welcome to the show, former U.S. Army Special Forces, and Security Studies Group president, Jim Hanson. Great to see you, Jim. So, the threat of being cut off from the U.S. financial system is it enough for European companies to say you know what, we're not going to help Iran with its major exports of Islamic revolution, right?

JIM HANSON, PRESIDENT, SECURITY STUDIES GROUP: I don't think it's a tough question from a business perspective when you look at the size of the economy in Iran and the size of the economy in the United States. So that's an easy case to make.

You add on top of that, the fact that Iran is the most malevolent force in the region, they sponsor terror all over the place and they're oppressing their own people, stealing their wealth. I don't think it's something that any decent country should be able to countenance. And right now, they seem to be stepping in line and that's good.

MACDONALD: You know, Jim, it looks like we're in a hinge point right now. And interesting development. Europe was thought to be saying to Iran we will still work with you on a nuclear deal.

But now this, Germany, we know that Germany is Europe's economic engine. The fact that, Jim, it's reportedly moving to stop Iran from getting $400 million in cash out of Germany is significant because Germany's central bank often partnered with Iran to circumvent U.S. sanctions.

HANSON: And now you've got a 100 percent clear message coming out of the U.S. administration. President Trump said, do business with them, don't do be with us. John Bolton said, don't buy their oil, stop buying playing with the mullahs. It's crystal clear. And it's fair.

You know, the mullahs have stolen when Obama sent all that cash over on planes, the Iranian people thought maybe they may get a little bit of win fall from that. Instead it all was stolen by the mullahs or sent to Hamas and Hezbollah and other terror groups.

MACDONALD: And--

HANSON: So it's time to change that around and use the money for good.

MACDONALD: And Jim, it seems like the Iranian people are saying to Europe, stand with us, and not those oppressing us. They seems to be saying to the Democrats and liberal left here in the United States, you, liberal left and Democrats, stand with the people in the streets of Iran and not those oppressing us.

We have President Hassan Rouhani he is now saying Iran cannot talk to the U.S. while under sanctions. Let's a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HASSAN ROUHANI, PRESIDENT OF IRAN (through translator): What's the meaning of negotiations when you impose sanctions at the same time? It's like someone pulling a knife, stab a rival or an enemy in the arms, while at the same time claiming we should be talking and negotiating.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Your reaction, Jim?

HANSON: Come on, Rouhani is a thug, and the bottom line is we don't have a whole lot to talk to him about. You are absolutely right saying that all decent people should be standing with the citizens of Iran, the people who want decent governing. They want to stop being, you have their money stolen and used for terrorism as opposed to giving them a decent standard of living.

So I think now that people are actually looking at that and saying, well, why would we stand? You know, the Obama administration decided that the Iranians were a partner for peace. They were wrong, now that reality has set back in, we can go ahead and flip that on its head and the mullahs need to suffer, not the people of Iran.

MACDONALD: Jim, we also have Trump national security advisor John Bolton explaining what it would take for a deal with Iran. Let's watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: The policy is not regime change, but we definitely want to put maximum pressure on the government.

We want to see a much broader retreat by Iran from their support for international terrorism, their belligerent military activity in the Middle East, and their ballistic missile nuclear related programs.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: All right. Here's a bit of a disconnect. The White House is saying it will go after and shut down Iran's oil exports but then it says it's not about regime change. Can you spell that for us?

HANSON: I think the correct policy is the one that John Bolton just outlined, we want the mullahs to change their malevolent ways. If they don't do that, who knows what the next step is, you know, it could be that they are replaced either by the people of Iran or by the simple fact that they end up bankrupt and unable to maintain their corrupt regime.

So, I don't think it's a question of the U.S. saying we think everyone there should change the regime. That's the Iranian people's choice. We just support their right to a decent government. And that's the right way for the U.S. to operate.

MACDONALD: Jim Hanson, president of Security Studies Group. Great to see you, Jim. Thanks for coming in.

HANSON: Good to be with you, Liz.

MACDONALD: Let's get to job. Job gains in the manufacturing sector, in the last 12 months, the most since 1995.

And look at this. As the president is moving to retrain our work force and get better education, we have former education secretary under President Obama, he is Arne Duncan, he criticize President Trump. Take a listen to what he said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ARNE DUNCAN, FORMER SECRETARY, U.S. DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION: I'm not sure President Trump wants to have the best educated workforce.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Why is that?

DUNCAN: I think it doesn't play to his authoritarian tendencies. He don't want highly educated people challenging his thinking. He is trying to call the press the enemy of the people. He is trying to suppress trust in institutions. Having thoughtful people who think on themselves -- think by themselves think critically. I'm not sure if that's in his self interest.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Well, we welcome to the show for her reaction from the Fiscal Times star columnist, Liz Peek. Great to see you. Your reaction to that?

LIZ PEEK, COLUMNIST, FISCAL TIMES: I think that's an appalling statement. And I have to say if any group could be accused of not wanting to educate the people, it's Democrats who basically are all in with the teacher's union oppose every kind of reform, come out as Hillary Clinton did and the ACP did against charter schools which in some cities like our own in Baltimore and other places is the only ticket for kids who are living in ghettos.

I mean, this is really -- and actually I'm really shocked by Arne Duncan because he was a school reformer if you remember in Chicago. Obama had hired him to be his education chief, and it wasn't until lead up to the 2012 election, when the teacher's union say, hey, you stop with these reforms or we're not going to back you, then he backed off.

MACDONALD: And he said, Arne Duncan said that President Trump wants to keep the American population uneducated and ignorant because he's authoritarian.

(CROSSTALK)

PEEK: That is an appalling -- yes, that's an appalling statement. And look, what is Trump actually doing? He's brought in Betsy DeVos, who is trying to further other avenues to education for kids that really need a leg up and haven't been able to get it through our public education system.

And more importantly, and I think very enthusiastically going after apprenticeships, which is all to do with educating the workforce and getting the people in a position where they can get jobs and make a living.

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: And learn a trade.

PEEK: Yes, exactly.

MACDONALD: Let's turn to this tweet that was heard around the world. Billionaire Elon Musk rocking the markets today, he basically said he wants to take Tesla private.

The shares are halted at about 367 a share, they did resumed trading. Musk saying he, again, wants to take this company, Tesla private. Now Tesla shares also jumping on a report that Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund bought a $2 billion minority stake in Tesla just below 5 percent.

Here is Musk's tweet. "I'm considering taking Tesla private at four -- 420 bucks. Funding secured."

Later company issued a blog post saying no final decision has been made on this. Musk clarifying in another tweet. "Investor support is confirmed. The only reason why this is not certain is that it's contingent on shareholder vote."

Look at the stock, surging more than 10 percent after the trading resume, closing out the day at 379 and change.

MACDONALD: That's OK. Understood. Well, we got one more minute to go. I don't understand why you're saying she is a capitalist because she is not a capitalist.

GOYLE: Look, I get -- I get what the objective here is, which is we need a liberal punching back because...

MACDONALD: No, no, you are not. I'm sorry.

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: Excuse me, Raj, Raj, you are not answering -- you're not answering the question of why you claimed she is a capitalist. We got to have to leave it there. Ford and Raj, thank you so much. I really appreciate it.

O'CONNELL: Ty, E-Mac.

GOYLE: Thank you.

MACDONALD: Now, we have a healthcare game-changer, carmaker GM working out a deal with a local hospital group, instead of dealing with insurers. GM saying it's a good thing. We got it coming up. Doc Siegel on that after the break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Well, look at this healthcare game-changer. Carmaker GM designing to offer a healthcare plan for workers. To break it down, Doc Siegel is here. Well, this is a big deal, Doc.

MARC SIEGEL, FOX BUSINESS: I like this.

MACDONALD: Why?

SIEGEL: You know why, it cuts out the middleman, it cuts down costs. The average is going to be $300 to $900 in premiums less. They are starting it out with 24,000 employees, but we know General Motors has 180,000 employees. And guess what they're using, Liz, the Henry Ford Healthcare System in Detroit. How ironic, General Motors going to Henry Ford Hospital. It's a very good hospital. They're going to be able to get next-day service. They're going to have access to 3,000 healthcare providers. You're going to get surgery. It's going to be all in one place. And you know what, prescription drug prices will be less because again, pharmacy benefit managers step in and take a profit for negotiating a deal. General Motors has the power behind it that they can negotiate directly with healthcare providers, lower costs and lower prices.

MACDONALD: OK, so, GM is handling it. How are they going to protect them bottom-line by doing it this way.

SIEGEL: I think they're going to do that because it is going to cut out waste. So the bottom-line will be -- will be better, though actually not waste money. So, again, the money doesn't get chewed up by GM. It gets chewed up the middleman.

MACDONALD: You like this. It sounds you really like this.

SIEGEL: Well, Boeing is doing it. And Intel is doing it. And 11 percent of all employers are doing it. Everybody knows that the money in the healthcare system is not lost with the doctor or the patient or even the employer. It's lost with the insurance companies and with the pharmacy benefit managers.

MACDONALD: Wow, what a story. Can you come back on and we'll talk more about it?

SIEGEL: I'm very excited about this. It is a private way to cut down healthcare cost.

MACDONALD: Doc Siegel, we love having you on.

SIEGEL: Good to see you.

MACDONALD: Come back soon. We're going to have more after the break, stay there.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Welcome back. Breaking news, the Trump White House set to impose a second set of tariffs on $16 billion worth of Chinese imports starting August 23rd. That's just two weeks away. We're going to stay on that story for you.

Well, thank you so much for having us in your homes. Thank you for watching. Adam Shapiro here now with "MAKING MONEY." Take it away, Adam.

END

Designing to Offer a Health Care Plan for WorkersLanhamFULL TEXT

MELISSA FRANCIS, FOX NEWS HOST: Amazing. EVENING EDIT starts right now.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN BOLTON, UNITED STATES NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISOR: We're intending to put unprecedented pressure on Iran. Their currency is going through the floor, much of that in the past 90 days.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Trump appears to be threatening any country that does business with Iran by blowing up the Iran deal.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: In the spring, we lost the support we had, which was hard to achieve from Russia and China, and obviously the E.U.

BOLTON: Why do you want to do business with the world's largest financier of international terrorism? Really, the central bank of international terrorism. Do your shareholders feel good that you are doing business with a terrorist regime, that's the sort of thing I think everybody needs to ask.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ELIZABETH MACDONALD, FOX NEWS HOST: And the pressure is now on. President Trump warning European countries -- companies, you do business with Iran, you will not be doing business with the United States.

Now look at this. German carmaker Daimler did changed its expansion plans in Iran. So who is next to fall in line? We've got the names coming up. And you will not believe which European country is now stepping up.

And Iran's President Hassan Rouhani saying Iran cannot negotiate with U.S. while under sanctions. Accusing the U.S. of, quote, "psychological warfare." We debate that.

And coming up too, the latest on conservatives getting assaulted in public.

And also this, Tesla stock halted in trading today after billionaire, speaking of Elon Musk, he tweeted out that he may take Tesla's private. It was a tweet heard around the world. We've got the latest on that, and also Disney earnings and more.

Well, thank you so much for joining us. Thank you for watching. Money, politics, we've got the debate behind tomorrow's headlines. I'm Elizabeth MacDonald. THE EVENING EDIT starts right now.

All right. Let's get right to your money. Look at this. The Dow finishing up 126 points to 25,628. It's sleepy August, the Dow continues to go up. The S&P climbing to less than 1 percent from a new record. Tesla and Amazon on the move. More on your money in just a second.

But first, President Trump sanctions on Iran went into effect today, and businesses from Berlin, Paris, Rome to London now feeling pressure to back off from doing business in Iran.

And Germany is the country now stepping up and reportedly moving to stop the transfer of nearly $400 million in cash out of Germany to the Iranian regime. Iran wants its money. They want that 400 million now. To avoid that money being detained under looming sanctions.

While U.S. sanctions were also causing German auto giant Daimler, the maker of Mercedes, to abandon their expansion plans in Iran. Look at this. The maker of Peugeot cars, also the French oil company Total, and Germany's Siemens have also backed off.

A U.S. official now says nearly 100 international firms have announced they intend to leave Iran. Republican Senator Lindsey Graham also calling out to European companies saying it is time to make a choice.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R), SOUTH CAROLINA: What is it about the ayatollah that you like? Why do you stand with him and against the people he is oppressing? Why do you want to give a man more money who's taken the money you've already given him to build the war machine to dismember the Mideast.

Do you think he is kidding when he says death to Israel? To the Europeans, you need to get with the Iranian people, and get behind Trump to break this regime's back before it is too late.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Joining me now, we welcome to the show, former U.S. Army Special Forces, and Security Studies Group president, Jim Hanson. Great to see you, Jim. So, the threat of being cut off from the U.S. financial system is it enough for European companies to say you know what, we're not going to help Iran with its major exports of Islamic revolution, right?

JIM HANSON, PRESIDENT, SECURITY STUDIES GROUP: I don't think it's a tough question from a business perspective when you look at the size of the economy in Iran and the size of the economy in the United States. So that's an easy case to make.

You add on top of that, the fact that Iran is the most malevolent force in the region, they sponsor terror all over the place and they're oppressing their own people, stealing their wealth. I don't think it's something that any decent country should be able to countenance. And right now, they seem to be stepping in line and that's good.

MACDONALD: You know, Jim, it looks like we're in a hinge point right now. And interesting development. Europe was thought to be saying to Iran we will still work with you on a nuclear deal.

But now this, Germany, we know that Germany is Europe's economic engine. The fact that, Jim, it's reportedly moving to stop Iran from getting $400 million in cash out of Germany is significant because Germany's central bank often partnered with Iran to circumvent U.S. sanctions.

HANSON: And now you've got a 100 percent clear message coming out of the U.S. administration. President Trump said, do business with them, don't do be with us. John Bolton said, don't buy their oil, stop buying playing with the mullahs. It's crystal clear. And it's fair.

You know, the mullahs have stolen when Obama sent all that cash over on planes, the Iranian people thought maybe they may get a little bit of win fall from that. Instead it all was stolen by the mullahs or sent to Hamas and Hezbollah and other terror groups.

MACDONALD: And--

HANSON: So it's time to change that around and use the money for good.

MACDONALD: And Jim, it seems like the Iranian people are saying to Europe, stand with us, and not those oppressing us. They seems to be saying to the Democrats and liberal left here in the United States, you, liberal left and Democrats, stand with the people in the streets of Iran and not those oppressing us.

We have President Hassan Rouhani he is now saying Iran cannot talk to the U.S. while under sanctions. Let's a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HASSAN ROUHANI, PRESIDENT OF IRAN (through translator): What's the meaning of negotiations when you impose sanctions at the same time? It's like someone pulling a knife, stab a rival or an enemy in the arms, while at the same time claiming we should be talking and negotiating.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Your reaction, Jim?

HANSON: Come on, Rouhani is a thug, and the bottom line is we don't have a whole lot to talk to him about. You are absolutely right saying that all decent people should be standing with the citizens of Iran, the people who want decent governing. They want to stop being, you have their money stolen and used for terrorism as opposed to giving them a decent standard of living.

So I think now that people are actually looking at that and saying, well, why would we stand? You know, the Obama administration decided that the Iranians were a partner for peace. They were wrong, now that reality has set back in, we can go ahead and flip that on its head and the mullahs need to suffer, not the people of Iran.

MACDONALD: Jim, we also have Trump national security advisor John Bolton explaining what it would take for a deal with Iran. Let's watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: The policy is not regime change, but we definitely want to put maximum pressure on the government.

We want to see a much broader retreat by Iran from their support for international terrorism, their belligerent military activity in the Middle East, and their ballistic missile nuclear related programs.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: All right. Here's a bit of a disconnect. The White House is saying it will go after and shut down Iran's oil exports but then it says it's not about regime change. Can you spell that for us?

HANSON: I think the correct policy is the one that John Bolton just outlined, we want the mullahs to change their malevolent ways. If they don't do that, who knows what the next step is, you know, it could be that they are replaced either by the people of Iran or by the simple fact that they end up bankrupt and unable to maintain their corrupt regime.

So, I don't think it's a question of the U.S. saying we think everyone there should change the regime. That's the Iranian people's choice. We just support their right to a decent government. And that's the right way for the U.S. to operate.

MACDONALD: Jim Hanson, president of Security Studies Group. Great to see you, Jim. Thanks for coming in.

HANSON: Good to be with you, Liz.

MACDONALD: Let's get to job. Job gains in the manufacturing sector, in the last 12 months, the most since 1995.

And look at this. As the president is moving to retrain our work force and get better education, we have former education secretary under President Obama, he is Arne Duncan, he criticize President Trump. Take a listen to what he said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ARNE DUNCAN, FORMER SECRETARY, U.S. DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION: I'm not sure President Trump wants to have the best educated workforce.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Why is that?

DUNCAN: I think it doesn't play to his authoritarian tendencies. He don't want highly educated people challenging his thinking. He is trying to call the press the enemy of the people. He is trying to suppress trust in institutions. Having thoughtful people who think on themselves -- think by themselves think critically. I'm not sure if that's in his self interest.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: Well, we welcome to the show for her reaction from the Fiscal Times star columnist, Liz Peek. Great to see you. Your reaction to that?

LIZ PEEK, COLUMNIST, FISCAL TIMES: I think that's an appalling statement. And I have to say if any group could be accused of not wanting to educate the people, it's Democrats who basically are all in with the teacher's union oppose every kind of reform, come out as Hillary Clinton did and the ACP did against charter schools which in some cities like our own in Baltimore and other places is the only ticket for kids who are living in ghettos.

I mean, this is really -- and actually I'm really shocked by Arne Duncan because he was a school reformer if you remember in Chicago. Obama had hired him to be his education chief, and it wasn't until lead up to the 2012 election, when the teacher's union say, hey, you stop with these reforms or we're not going to back you, then he backed off.

MACDONALD: And he said, Arne Duncan said that President Trump wants to keep the American population uneducated and ignorant because he's authoritarian.

(CROSSTALK)

PEEK: That is an appalling -- yes, that's an appalling statement. And look, what is Trump actually doing? He's brought in Betsy DeVos, who is trying to further other avenues to education for kids that really need a leg up and haven't been able to get it through our public education system.

And more importantly, and I think very enthusiastically going after apprenticeships, which is all to do with educating the workforce and getting the people in a position where they can get jobs and make a living.

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: And learn a trade.

PEEK: Yes, exactly.

MACDONALD: Let's turn to this tweet that was heard around the world. Billionaire Elon Musk rocking the markets today, he basically said he wants to take Tesla private.

The shares are halted at about 367 a share, they did resumed trading. Musk saying he, again, wants to take this company, Tesla private. Now Tesla shares also jumping on a report that Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund bought a $2 billion minority stake in Tesla just below 5 percent.

Here is Musk's tweet. "I'm considering taking Tesla private at four -- 420 bucks. Funding secured."

Later company issued a blog post saying no final decision has been made on this. Musk clarifying in another tweet. "Investor support is confirmed. The only reason why this is not certain is that it's contingent on shareholder vote."

Look at the stock, surging more than 10 percent after the trading resume, closing out the day at 379 and change.

Liz, quite a development. Tesla going private.

PEEK: I mean, it's really kind of unheard of for a CEO to tweet a $70 billion transaction, but then a lot of things that this fellow does are pretty unusual including having to apologize on the latest on earnings call for bad manners.

I have to say, reading the blog post in which he enumerates the reasons for maybe wanting to go private, you kind of end up thinking he is a little bit of a brat, right? In other words, what's really bothering him, the scrutiny, the criticism.

MACDONALD: Sure.

PEEK: The fact that you have enormous shorts out there.

MACDONALD: Yes.

PEEK: And I'm sure he is delighting tonight in fact that those shorts took a huge hit. I've read the number, it's a pretty big number that they lost because the stock going up 10 percent.

MACDONALD: I don't -- you know, I can't recall having cover corporate accounting, and corporate accounting, I'm not saying this is a scandal, I just covered corporate accounting at the Wall Street Journal. I can't recall a company making such a significant statement that moves the market in such a material way by tweet.

PEEK: Yes.

MACDONALD: You got to wonder if the SEC is going to be taking a look.

PEEK: Well, Harvey Pitt has already come out and said, you know, perhaps this really wasn't legal. I suspect that because now--

(CROSSTALK)

MACDONALD: Harvey Pitt ran the FCC.

PEEK: Yes, former FCC head. I think it has now been judged that you can make public announcements via Twitter or Facebook, but this is sort of outrageous it seems to me in that the financing has not been lined up. Apparently if someone CNBC or someone went out and talked to all the banks, nobody is saying that they are behind what was it, $70 billion transaction.

MACDONALD: Wait a minute. If they did -- if he only had, well, it's a significant stake at the Saudi Arabia wealth fund.

(CROSSTALK)

PEEK: Well, it's $2 million.

MACDONALD: Well, yes, but it's a good presence to have in there (Inaudible) other banks in.

(CROSSTALK)

PEEK: Sure. But--

MACDONALD: But if there is no other bank funding there then he is going to--

(CROSSTALK)

PEEK: Who knows, right?

MACDONALD: -- he's in trouble, right?

PEEK: We'll see. I mean, you know, I read some of the discourse that came out after the earnings call, which was very bullish, if you remember. But then, a couple days later, as is their want they held up 10 Q. The financial report until after that earnings call.

And in that financial report there were some pretty troubling things about the balance sheet, which is really at issue here for this company. They're going to be -- they're saying they are going to be spending $2.5 billion a year. Some analysts think that is simply not enough to cover their expected capital and expenditures and interest payment. So I think there really are some questions to Tesla's solvency.

MACDONALD: Yes. I mean, the debt swamp the shareholder equities.

PEEK: Yes. And by the way, going private in some ways would be a good thing for Tesla. No question.

MACDONALD: Yes. I tell you something. When you factor in Musk ownership stake at around 90 percent, and the shorts at around 27, half of the company is either owned by the shorts or Musk. I mean, holy Toledo, what a story this is.

PEEK: It is a big story. No question.

MACDONALD: Liz, great to see you. Come back soon. We love having you on.

PEEK: Thank you. Thanks for having me.

MACDONALD: Let's get to your money. We really want to check what's going on with the markets closing in green. The Dow up 126 points. Walt Disney reporting a bit of disappointing third quarter. Studio revenue though, grew 20 percent year-over-year, with strong box office sales there.

Let's get right to Nicole Petallides on the floor of the NYSE with the latest. Nicole?

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Immediately following the numbers on Disney we saw Disney selling off, it missed on the estimates. And while it did well enough in the movie studio, they have higher programming cost, and the trend from ESPN continues losing subscribers there. Watch Disney tomorrow in the trade.

In the meantime, the Dow, the NASDAQ and the S&P moved higher. The Dow up 127 points. And the S&P 500 about half a percent away from its all-time high.

It is worth noting that as for highs, notable highs, Disney hit a multiyear high as did Pfizer and Merck. And guess what. Apple hit an all-time high today as well. I know it pulled back but they are breaking out a little bit testing the top. Back to you.

MACDONALD: All right. Thank you, Nicole. We're going to stay on the story about billionaire Elon Musk, confirming his intention to go private via tweet. Is this a brave new world for all investors that CEOs could tweet out information that rocks the markets and change the value of their 401Ks? We're staying on that story for you throughout the hour.

Also tonight, a video now going viral. Ivy League millennials trying to explain what their understanding of the First Amendment is. It did not go well.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Any come to mind freedom is under the First Amendment.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Freedom of--

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MACDONALD: So at an average 60k a year in tuition what are professors teaching their kids. We're going to play the full exchange, coming up.

Also tonight, a new report, Democrats using the fake news crackdown to try to grab more government control of the internet. Judge Andrew Napolitano says watch out, it's an attack in your First Amendment rights. He's here to talk about it.

But first, voting now underway in five states. Bernie Sanders jumping for a Michigan gubernatorial candidate, Abdul El-Sayed. He's looking to implement a bunch of socialist policies in that state. We've got the details and the debate, coming up. Stay there.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MACDONALD: Voting underway in five states today. Primaries in Kansas, Michigan, Missouri and Washington. And we have a special House election in Ohio's 12th district. This as socialist Bernie Sanders is stumping for a Michigan gubernatorial candidate, Abdul El-Sayed.

He's looking to implement socialist policies like, state level single payer healthcare, free college tuition, end the state's anti-union laws it's called right to work.

Let's bring in Wall Street Journal editorial board member, look who's here, Bill McGurn. You know, Bill, here's the thing with the socialist. I mean, Alexandria Cortez won 16,000 of the vote.

urn:contentItem:5R3T-D261-JBG3-64KH-00000-00The Trump Administration’s Incoherent Stance on Competition;Op-Ed Contributor2017-11-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:35:40ZLexisNexisOPINIONThe Trump Administration’s Incoherent Stance on CompetitionOp-Ed ContributorJONATHAN TAPLIN

It’s planning to end net neutrality while opposing the Time Warner and AT&T merger. This doesn’t make sense.

Peter Thiel, Facebook’s first outside investor, once wrote: “Competition is for losers. If you want to create and capture lasting value, look to build a monopoly.” Executives at Facebook, Google and Amazon seem to have taken his blunt advice.

If only the Trump administration could be so clear when it comes to its stance on competition. Instead, it has sent a schizophrenic message, which means the few remaining companies with a chance to rival big tech have no way of knowing where the administration stands or what values it will enforce.

On the one hand, the F.C.C. has signaled it will eliminate net neutrality, the rule that ensures equal access to the internet for all websites. If this happens, internet service providers like Comcast, Verizon and AT&T will be able to charge extra fees for high-quality streaming and exclude certain content from the all-in data plans they offer. Critics say this move would be devastating to the websites and applications that can’t pay the fees.

On the other hand, just a day before the F.C.C. announcement, the Justice Department communicated starkly different values. Announcing its opposition to the proposed merger of Time Warner and AT&T, it used an argument based on the very kind of thinking that’s often used to defend net neutrality: The department made the case that if the merger were allowed to go through, AT&T might favor the Time Warner content it would own post-merger, to the disadvantage of rivals.

The incoherence of these conflicting positions on competition is staggering, but this kind of cognitive dissonance is not unique. Don’t forget that the Obama administration — at the behest of Amazon, which controlled almost 80 percent of the online book market — brought an antitrust suit alleging Apple and five publishers colluded on pricing for digital books. That administration did not have a consistent view of media monopoly power that is enforced equally on all parties, and neither does the current one.

For instance, internet service providers operate under a totally different set of privacy regulations than the online service providers (like Google and Facebook) that dominate the online advertising market. According to Morgan Stanley, Google and Facebook took an astonishing 85 percent of all new online ad revenue last year. And yet Google spends millions lobbying Congress to prevent any rivals from entering its unique surveillance capitalism business. Essentially, the government is giving a pass to the largest media advertising firms that have no restrictions on consumer privacy, while suing to block potential rival services that operate under strict privacy restrictions.

It could be that the notion of net neutrality that the F.C.C. seems determined to jettison should also be applied to media monopolies. When the European Union fined Google $2.7 billion in June for unfairly favoring some of its own services over those of rivals, it was essentially for a violation of neutrality: The union noted that Google was both a service provider (that users could use to conduct searches) and a content provider (that provided its own restaurant, hotel and other product recommendations) and was favoring its own content in search results over that of rivals that also provided recommendations, like Yelp.

Of course, being buried deep in Google’s search results or being forced to pay Google for prominent placement hurts smaller firms. This is arguably no less harmful to a business than being forced to pay Verizon for good video quality for its streaming site — the fate that many content producers will meet if net neutrality rules are rolled back under the plan the F.C.C. has hinted at. It is what economists call “rent seeking,” and it is a cancer on any open media system in any context, but the Trump administration doesn’t treat it the same in all contexts.

Mr. Trump is nothing if not sensitive to a populist uprising, and the net neutrality decision will probably be opposed on both the left and right. It could be that during the F.C.C.’s comment period, the resistance to overturning net neutrality may be too strong and the ruling will be withdrawn.

But that leaves the larger questions unanswered. What exactly would a consistent antitrust policy for the media sector look like? Is it possible to reconcile the conflicting signals from the F.C.C. and the Department of Justice?

The answer is that regulators must realize where the real market power lies and use this as the basis for their decisions about competition. Time Warner’s market capitalization is $70 billion. Google is worth 10 times as much, at $723 billion. Turner Broadcasting, Time Warner’s largest advertising subsidiary, brought in $1.2 billion in ad revenue in the last quarter, while Google reported $22.5 billion in ad revenue in the same period. It should be noted that AT&T has almost no appreciable ad revenue. So, if there is to be a coherent approach to competition, the Federal Trade Commission, which regulates Google and Facebook, and the F.C.C., which regulates AT&T, must find common ground on the regulation of ad-supported content networks.

For the Trump administration to try to block the merger of two relatively small media players while letting Google operate freely with no privacy restrictions is to be fighting the last war. The notion that television is the major media power in America ignores reality. It may be that the assistant attorney general for antitrust, Makan Delrahim, has a decent case that internet service providers and content providers need some sort of separation. But if that is true, then the same rules on neutrality and consumer privacy need to apply to companies like Google, Facebook and Amazon — and the F.C.C. should keep net neutrality rules in place.

The administration can’t have it both ways.

Follow The New York Times Opinion section on Facebook and   Twitter (@NYTopinion), and sign up for the   Opinion Today newsletter.

Jonathan Taplin is the director emeritus of the Annenberg Innovation Lab at the University of Southern California and the author of “Move Fast and Break Things: How Facebook, Google and Amazon Cornered Culture and Undermined Democracy.”

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Friday. It is Friday, November 9th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the button on the East Coast.

Investors are on edge this morning. Take a look at futures, indicating a triple digit decline at the start of trading, down 130 points on the Dow, down 16 on the S&P, down 61 points on the Nasdaq -- almost 1 percent.

This after a mixed story yesterday.

The Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged as expected. But some thought the central bank would signal a dovish tone following the market volatility last month. We did not see that.

DowIndustrials were up 11 points. S&P 500 down 7. Nasdaq down 39 at the close yesterday.

Global markets this morning also under pressure. FT 100 in London down almost 1 percent. The CAC 40 in Paris down better than 1 percent and the DAX index in Germany down two-thirds of 1 percent.

In Asia overnight, declines across the board. Worst performer Hong Kong better than 2 percent lower.

Meanwhile oil entering a bear market. Oil prices are now down 20 percent from their most recent high. Why it could be a warning for what's to come in the global economy.

Plus, madam speaker, House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi standing firm that she will get that gavel back.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA), HOUSE MINORITY LEADER: I will be the speaker of the people's House. I feel very confident about where I am. And I feel very encouraged by the overwhelming support in my caucus that will go to the floor.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Well, she may still face a tough road to victory. We're taking a look at the race for house speaker this morning.

And a bomb shell lawsuit in Florida -- Rick Scott is alleging Democrats were trying to steal the election. The details later this hour as Florida is looking at a recount.

All those stories coming up this Friday morning. And joining me to break it all down -- Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell; Rosecliff CEO and managing partner Mike Murphy; and former Utah Congressman, former House Oversight Committee chairman and Fox News contributor Jason Chaffetz. Good morning.

JASON CHAFFETZ, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you.

CHAFFETZ: What a week.

BARTIROMO: What a week. It's been an incredible week. A lot of news and we have a lot of open questions still.

CHAFFETZ: Yes. Yes. From the firing of Jeff Sessions which we forgot to mention earlier in the list of things to an amazing election to the President traveling overseas. He's got a lot on his plate.

BARTIROMO: Yes. He's headed to Paris. And we're going to probably see him leave this morning. What's on your mind?

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: But now with Florida and the -- again, we know that the Republicans will hold a majority in the Senate but you have Sinema now leading McSally in the vote count in Arizona. Florida headed for a recount. Some shenanigans going on according to Governor Rick Scott there.

And so there's a lot of -- a lot is up in the air at this point.

CHAFFETZ: Even the Georgia governor's race is still --

BARTIROMO: Yes. Even the Georgia's governor's -- that's right.

MIKE MURPHY, MANAGING PARTNER, ROSECLIFF: My glass being half full, I'm hoping that now we have some bipartisanship that somehow we get -- instead of just everyone attacking everyone, we get some people working together.

BARTIROMO: Well, that's why the markets I guess rallied. Maybe markets like the divided government -- 545 points higher on the Dow the day after the midterms.

MURPHY: Yes. And you know, one, it took a lot of the uncertainty out. But two, I think we sold off into the elections because we weren't sure what the outcomes were going to be. So getting some of that back.

But now, for the last two months of the year, we have to see if big tech can resume its leadership in the market.

MCDOWELL: I don't know if I would cut a deal with somebody who is not acting in your best interest. I will say that about Washington, Jason Chaffetz.

CHAFFETZ: I'm trying to get to one over here. I sat for two years when Nancy Pelosi was the speaker, I didn't see an ounce of bipartisanship in those two years. So color me tainted but I've got to tell you, I sat there and saw it for myself.

And I don't think -- she said she has the overwhelming majority but she needs 218 people specifically to vote for her as speaker. And she is not there yet.

BARTIROMO: You know, when I turned on the TV yesterday and I saw her at the podium speaking and doing this long press conference, I said, it's going to be a long couple of years. She's going to be at that podium talking about everything she wants.

MCDOWELL: But don't underestimate her though because I sat here repeatedly and mocked and disparaged that crumbs comment about the $2,000 bonuses that companies handed out but, you know what, she dropped that, didn't she. And she focused solely on the issue of health care.

Quite frankly, I think the Democrats and the messaging made that the number one issue. They preyed on people's fears about pre-existing condition coverage and it helped them in the House, most definitely.

BARTIROMO: And she probably will get the job because of her fund raising efforts. Isn't she a master fundraiser -- Jason.

CHAFFETZ: In the history of the United States Congress, the House and the Senate, nobody has ever raised more money than Nancy Pelosi. That's why she's at the top of the heap. But she's not the speaker yet.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll see. You're really skeptical she's going to get that 218.

CHAFFETZ: She's going to put a couple of dozen members in jeopardy because they all pledged that they would never vote for Nancy Pelosi to be the speaker. It's a real dilemma for her.

MCDOWELL: The Democratic House candidates this cycle, we don't even have the final tally, raised $1 billion. And that's 50 percent more than the Republicans raised.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, they definitely out-raised the Republicans this season as well.

CHAFFETZ: I'm so glad I'm out of the business of raising money, I tell you that. I hated it.

BARTIROMO: I bet. I bet. That's hard.

We have a lot coming up in all of the above. But let's get to our top story this hour. And that is President Trump reaching across the aisle to keep driving strong economic growth in the U.S.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Now is the time for members of both parties to join together, put partisanship aside, and keep the American economic miracle going strong. It is a miracle. We're doing so well.

And I've said it at a lot of rallies. Some of you have probably heard it so much, you don't want to hear it again. But when people come to my office -- presidents, prime ministers, they all congratulate me, almost the first thing on what we've done economically because it is really amazing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now is Oppenheimer Funds chief investment officer, Krishna Memani. Krishna -- good to see you.

KRISHNA MEMANI, CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER, OPPENHEIMER FUNDS: Good to see you as well.

BARTIROMO: And you do -- you agree that the economy is amazing and doing well but you see a slowdown on the horizon.

MEMANI: Yes. I think the economy today is doing reasonably well. We are probably going to end up somewhere north of 3 percent for the year.

But I think the slowdown is already unfolding. So by the middle of next year, we are talking about getting back to close to 2 percent rather than 3 percent that we have seen in 2018.

BARTIROMO: Do you think the slowdown is based only on higher interest rates? I mean the Fed left interest rates unchanged yesterday but it does look like we're going to see a rate hike in the month of December. Is that what's slowing things down or something else?

MEMANI: Well, that certainly is slowing things down a tad. But I think part of it is because the capital spending cycle that we expected -- the capital spending boost never materialized.

So for the economy to get to a higher level, we need higher level of productivity. And productivity is improving but not to the level that we need it to be.

BARTIROMO: We've talked about this a lot -- Dagen. The cap -- one second, Mike -- I'm sorry. But the cap ex -- when the President rolled back and Congress rolled back all of those regulations earlier, you know, early in his administration, cap spending did increase. And we were like oh, businesses have been sitting on cash for 10 years, they're finally putting it to work.

Was it trade, do you think, the worries over steel and aluminum that stopped businesses to say wait, let me -- I'm not sure about this. I'm going to sit on cash again.

MCDOWELL: Hard to quantify but likely playing into that decision making because business expenditures in the first quarter, I think were up 11.5 percent.

MEMANI: Sure.

MCDOWELL: In the most recent quarter that we got, in the third quarter, they were up only eight-tenths of a percent. Can that -- is this just a momentary kind of waning because of the concerns about trade.

We've gotten the Canada and the Mexico deal done and these get ratified by Congress. There's movement with Europe. Is that really what's in the way? Or -- is it just a momentary pause heading toward the end of the year.

MEMANI: Look, I think from a cyclical standpoint in this cycle capital spending never got to the level that it has in the past. And I think the likelihood that will get there this late in the cycle is probably very small.

BARTIROMO: Right.

MEMANI: Having said that, the capital spending is higher at this point in the cycle than it was in the beginning. But it's not enough to get us to 3 percent growth rate, I don't think.

MURPHY: I'm going to push back a little bit here because for investors at home watching this, you know, trying to time the market, you know, I'm sure you heard the saying it's not timing the market, it's your time in the market. So to try to reallocate assets out of funds or if you're planning for a slowdown, I think it's very dangerous for people to start to take their retirement funds for instance and say well, I'm going to move over here, now reallocating on an active basis.

I would advise people watching at home that we're going to go through ups and downs in the market --

MEMANI: Sure.

MURPHY: -- but stay invested because investors will typically panic out at the wrong time like last month and then not know when to get back in.

MEMANI: I couldn't agree with you more. Far from telling people to get out of the market, you kind of go back and look at things. In this cycle the most amount of money that you have made is just being there, rather than being out of the market.

Our view right now is five more years. That is this cycle will probably last another three, four, five years. It's not ending in 2019 or 2020 that some people are forecasting.

At this point, there's enough momentum in the economy to carry us through for a long time. Inflation hasn't manifested itself. So absolutely stay in the markets. There's no reason to take your money home just yet.

BETSY NUNEZ, CO-FOUNDER AND CHIEF OPERATING OFFICER, SWORD AND PLOUGH: Thank you for having us, Maria.

EMILY NUNEZ-CAVNESS, CEO, SWORD AND PLOUGH: Great to see you.

BARTIROMO: I'm just -- you know, you just get me -- I mean, I'm in awe knowing that you are in Kandahar Afghanistan, what you've done, your father is one of the great vets as well. Thank you for your service.

NUNEZ: Thank you so much. We are just thrilled to be here, especially right before Veterans Day which is incredibly important to Sword and Plough our mission.

BARTIROMO: Why is the company called Sword and Plough?

CAVNESS: So, it comes from the phrase to turns swords into ploughshares, which means to take a military technology and apply it to a peaceful civilian application. And that's really exactly what we're doing with our made in America products and repurposing thousands and thousands of military surplus into all of our designs.

BARTIROMO: I love this. And the last time you came you had lots of camo products. Now, you have little camo and tell me about what the products are this time.

CAVNESS: Sure, so we've got an assortment. We have everything from jewelry, necklaces, earrings made out of repurposed bullet casing, 50 caliber shell casing.

BARTIROMO: Nice. My goodness, you're kidding.

CAVNESS: Hand-hammered by an incredible female vet in Kentucky named Shana. And then we've got assortment of everything from bags to travel kits, essentially anything for you, a family member, loved one and they make perfect gifts for the holiday.

BARTIROMO: What's the best selling item?

NUNEZ: Our best sellers are definitely our necklaces. They're just so one of a kind. They don't look anything like what they're made out of. This big 50 caliber shell casing, and so, that's been a big hit.

BARTIROMO: So, tell me how that's done with the casing?

NUNEZ: Sure, this amazing veteran named Shana is in Kentucky, and she actually hand hammers every single bullet casing into this beautiful pieces of jewelry. And she actually was a 50 caliber machine gunner when she was in the Army and when she was deployed in Afghanistan. So, it's an amazing full circle -- full circle experience.

BARTIROMO: It is incredible.

CAVNESS: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Tell us about the events you have on top this month.

CAVNESS: Yes, so, we're gearing up for Veterans Day, obviously, big this Sunday, and then gearing up for holiday season. But today, we're donating 10 percent of profits from any of the sales on our website SwordandPlough.com to bumper labs. And they do incredible work. They are helping veterans and military spouses start their own business. So the sale of our products and the production of our products helps support veteran employment and empowerment at every stage in our business. And for your viewers we have a special code, FOX10, for 10 percent off for today through the weekend.

BARTIROMO: Thank you for that discount for our viewers.

CAVNESS: Of course.

BARTIROMO: And not only that, but it's real quality.

NUNEZ: Thank you, they last forever.

BARTIROMO: They last forever.

NUNEZ: We also have a steadfast guarantee. So if anything should ever happen, we repair it free of cost.

BARTIROMO: Give me the average prices here.

CAVNESS: Sure, we've got everything from $19.00 to $350, we do free shipping on all orders $200 and up. And everything from tote bag that makes a great diaper bag or bag for work to a cosmetic case or a toiletry case if you're traveling or if your husband needs an upgrade for the -- for the bathroom sink.

BARTIROMO: Very cool. Emily and Betsy, great to see you again. Thanks so much.

NUNEZ: Thank you -- thank you so much, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Happy Veterans Day to you both and to your father. Emily Nunez-Cavness and Betsy Nunez. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

END
