urn:contentItem:5TP6-HDC1-JB20-G3Y9-00000-00The Trump Economy; California Mass Shooting; Interview with Deepak Chopra; Nancy Pelosi: "100 percent Confident" She Will be the Next House Speaker; Rick Scott (R) Cites "Rampant Fraud" in Florida as Senate Race Tightens; Three Wildfires Hit California; Aldi Wine Calendar; Veteran-Owned Company Supports and Honors Vets2018-11-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:35:40ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA7:00 AM ESTMike Murphy, Krishna Memani, Deepak Chopra, Emily Nunez Cavness, Betsy Nunez, Kelly Jane TorranceNEWSFinancial110902cb.231The Trump Economy; California Mass Shooting; Interview with Deepak Chopra; Nancy Pelosi: "100 percent Confident" She Will be the Next House Speaker; Rick Scott (R) Cites "Rampant Fraud" in Florida as Senate Race Tightens; Three Wildfires Hit California; Aldi Wine Calendar; Veteran-Owned Company Supports and Honors VetsMaria Bartiromo, Jason Chaffetz, Dagen McDowell, Jonathan Hunt, Cheryl Casone

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us.

I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Friday. It is Friday, November 9th.

Your top stories right now at 7:00 a.m. on the button on the East Coast.

Investors are on edge this morning. Take a look at futures, indicating a triple digit decline at the start of trading, down 130 points on the Dow, down 16 on the S&P, down 61 points on the Nasdaq -- almost 1 percent.

This after a mixed story yesterday.

The Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged as expected. But some thought the central bank would signal a dovish tone following the market volatility last month. We did not see that.

DowIndustrials were up 11 points. S&P 500 down 7. Nasdaq down 39 at the close yesterday.

Global markets this morning also under pressure. FT 100 in London down almost 1 percent. The CAC 40 in Paris down better than 1 percent and the DAX index in Germany down two-thirds of 1 percent.

In Asia overnight, declines across the board. Worst performer Hong Kong better than 2 percent lower.

Meanwhile oil entering a bear market. Oil prices are now down 20 percent from their most recent high. Why it could be a warning for what's to come in the global economy.

Plus, madam speaker, House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi standing firm that she will get that gavel back.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA), HOUSE MINORITY LEADER: I will be the speaker of the people's House. I feel very confident about where I am. And I feel very encouraged by the overwhelming support in my caucus that will go to the floor.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Well, she may still face a tough road to victory. We're taking a look at the race for house speaker this morning.

And a bomb shell lawsuit in Florida -- Rick Scott is alleging Democrats were trying to steal the election. The details later this hour as Florida is looking at a recount.

All those stories coming up this Friday morning. And joining me to break it all down -- Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell; Rosecliff CEO and managing partner Mike Murphy; and former Utah Congressman, former House Oversight Committee chairman and Fox News contributor Jason Chaffetz. Good morning.

JASON CHAFFETZ, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you.

CHAFFETZ: What a week.

BARTIROMO: What a week. It's been an incredible week. A lot of news and we have a lot of open questions still.

CHAFFETZ: Yes. Yes. From the firing of Jeff Sessions which we forgot to mention earlier in the list of things to an amazing election to the President traveling overseas. He's got a lot on his plate.

BARTIROMO: Yes. He's headed to Paris. And we're going to probably see him leave this morning. What's on your mind?

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: But now with Florida and the -- again, we know that the Republicans will hold a majority in the Senate but you have Sinema now leading McSally in the vote count in Arizona. Florida headed for a recount. Some shenanigans going on according to Governor Rick Scott there.

And so there's a lot of -- a lot is up in the air at this point.

CHAFFETZ: Even the Georgia governor's race is still --

BARTIROMO: Yes. Even the Georgia's governor's -- that's right.

MIKE MURPHY, MANAGING PARTNER, ROSECLIFF: My glass being half full, I'm hoping that now we have some bipartisanship that somehow we get -- instead of just everyone attacking everyone, we get some people working together.

BARTIROMO: Well, that's why the markets I guess rallied. Maybe markets like the divided government -- 545 points higher on the Dow the day after the midterms.

MURPHY: Yes. And you know, one, it took a lot of the uncertainty out. But two, I think we sold off into the elections because we weren't sure what the outcomes were going to be. So getting some of that back.

But now, for the last two months of the year, we have to see if big tech can resume its leadership in the market.

MCDOWELL: I don't know if I would cut a deal with somebody who is not acting in your best interest. I will say that about Washington, Jason Chaffetz.

CHAFFETZ: I'm trying to get to one over here. I sat for two years when Nancy Pelosi was the speaker, I didn't see an ounce of bipartisanship in those two years. So color me tainted but I've got to tell you, I sat there and saw it for myself.

And I don't think -- she said she has the overwhelming majority but she needs 218 people specifically to vote for her as speaker. And she is not there yet.

BARTIROMO: You know, when I turned on the TV yesterday and I saw her at the podium speaking and doing this long press conference, I said, it's going to be a long couple of years. She's going to be at that podium talking about everything she wants.

MCDOWELL: But don't underestimate her though because I sat here repeatedly and mocked and disparaged that crumbs comment about the $2,000 bonuses that companies handed out but, you know what, she dropped that, didn't she. And she focused solely on the issue of health care.

Quite frankly, I think the Democrats and the messaging made that the number one issue. They preyed on people's fears about pre-existing condition coverage and it helped them in the House, most definitely.

BARTIROMO: And she probably will get the job because of her fund raising efforts. Isn't she a master fundraiser -- Jason.

CHAFFETZ: In the history of the United States Congress, the House and the Senate, nobody has ever raised more money than Nancy Pelosi. That's why she's at the top of the heap. But she's not the speaker yet.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll see. You're really skeptical she's going to get that 218.

CHAFFETZ: She's going to put a couple of dozen members in jeopardy because they all pledged that they would never vote for Nancy Pelosi to be the speaker. It's a real dilemma for her.

MCDOWELL: The Democratic House candidates this cycle, we don't even have the final tally, raised $1 billion. And that's 50 percent more than the Republicans raised.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, they definitely out-raised the Republicans this season as well.

CHAFFETZ: I'm so glad I'm out of the business of raising money, I tell you that. I hated it.

BARTIROMO: I bet. I bet. That's hard.

We have a lot coming up in all of the above. But let's get to our top story this hour. And that is President Trump reaching across the aisle to keep driving strong economic growth in the U.S.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Now is the time for members of both parties to join together, put partisanship aside, and keep the American economic miracle going strong. It is a miracle. We're doing so well.

And I've said it at a lot of rallies. Some of you have probably heard it so much, you don't want to hear it again. But when people come to my office -- presidents, prime ministers, they all congratulate me, almost the first thing on what we've done economically because it is really amazing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now is Oppenheimer Funds chief investment officer, Krishna Memani. Krishna -- good to see you.

KRISHNA MEMANI, CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER, OPPENHEIMER FUNDS: Good to see you as well.

BARTIROMO: And you do -- you agree that the economy is amazing and doing well but you see a slowdown on the horizon.

MEMANI: Yes. I think the economy today is doing reasonably well. We are probably going to end up somewhere north of 3 percent for the year.

But I think the slowdown is already unfolding. So by the middle of next year, we are talking about getting back to close to 2 percent rather than 3 percent that we have seen in 2018.

BARTIROMO: Do you think the slowdown is based only on higher interest rates? I mean the Fed left interest rates unchanged yesterday but it does look like we're going to see a rate hike in the month of December. Is that what's slowing things down or something else?

MEMANI: Well, that certainly is slowing things down a tad. But I think part of it is because the capital spending cycle that we expected -- the capital spending boost never materialized.

So for the economy to get to a higher level, we need higher level of productivity. And productivity is improving but not to the level that we need it to be.

BARTIROMO: We've talked about this a lot -- Dagen. The cap -- one second, Mike -- I'm sorry. But the cap ex -- when the President rolled back and Congress rolled back all of those regulations earlier, you know, early in his administration, cap spending did increase. And we were like oh, businesses have been sitting on cash for 10 years, they're finally putting it to work.

Was it trade, do you think, the worries over steel and aluminum that stopped businesses to say wait, let me -- I'm not sure about this. I'm going to sit on cash again.

MCDOWELL: Hard to quantify but likely playing into that decision making because business expenditures in the first quarter, I think were up 11.5 percent.

MEMANI: Sure.

MCDOWELL: In the most recent quarter that we got, in the third quarter, they were up only eight-tenths of a percent. Can that -- is this just a momentary kind of waning because of the concerns about trade.

We've gotten the Canada and the Mexico deal done and these get ratified by Congress. There's movement with Europe. Is that really what's in the way? Or -- is it just a momentary pause heading toward the end of the year.

MEMANI: Look, I think from a cyclical standpoint in this cycle capital spending never got to the level that it has in the past. And I think the likelihood that will get there this late in the cycle is probably very small.

BARTIROMO: Right.

MEMANI: Having said that, the capital spending is higher at this point in the cycle than it was in the beginning. But it's not enough to get us to 3 percent growth rate, I don't think.

MURPHY: I'm going to push back a little bit here because for investors at home watching this, you know, trying to time the market, you know, I'm sure you heard the saying it's not timing the market, it's your time in the market. So to try to reallocate assets out of funds or if you're planning for a slowdown, I think it's very dangerous for people to start to take their retirement funds for instance and say well, I'm going to move over here, now reallocating on an active basis.

I would advise people watching at home that we're going to go through ups and downs in the market --

MEMANI: Sure.

MURPHY: -- but stay invested because investors will typically panic out at the wrong time like last month and then not know when to get back in.

MEMANI: I couldn't agree with you more. Far from telling people to get out of the market, you kind of go back and look at things. In this cycle the most amount of money that you have made is just being there, rather than being out of the market.

Our view right now is five more years. That is this cycle will probably last another three, four, five years. It's not ending in 2019 or 2020 that some people are forecasting.

At this point, there's enough momentum in the economy to carry us through for a long time. Inflation hasn't manifested itself. So absolutely stay in the markets. There's no reason to take your money home just yet.

BARTIROMO: I want to ask you about trade because the U.S. and China are locked in a stalemate over trade. Despite the tensions, October saw a reported 30 percent increase in Chinese exports to the United States from a year ago.

This a Secretary of State Mike Pompeo and Defense Secretary Jim Mattis are scheduled to meet with their Chinese counterparts in Washington today. So I want to ask you about the Chinese strategy. But first there's an article in the "Journal" today which is questioning this new house leadership and what that does for USMCA.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: So we're supposed to see this ratified by Congress as Dagen just noted in the New Year. Do the Democrats stop this? Do they force -- you know, just because they've taken over the House majority or is it all about the Senate?

CHAFFETZ: It's really hard to see where they're coming from as long as this leadership race is still in play. I don't think they take a hard position and go to the President and say this is what we need out of it. I don't think that happens.

BARTIROMO: So you think it gets ratified.

CHAFFETZ: I do think it ultimately gets ratified because I think blue collar America wants it to happen.

MEMANI: I think it gets ratified for the simple reason that it's really good policy. I think free trade is a good thing. If you kind of go back and look at the Chinese data that you were talking about, at the end of the day trade hasn't really gone down meaningfully.

What has risen is basically tension in people's minds and that's kind of ending up taking away from capital spending that we need at this point.

MCDOWELL: One thing to note is -- in this "Wall Street Journal" article that Maria mentioned -- the unions will put pressure on the Democrat to ratify this. This is a huge win for the auto workers in this country because it discourages auto manufacturers from moving production down to Mexico for cheap labor. It's a big win.

And quite frankly, the steel tariffs are a big win for the steelworkers of the country. So they've got a lot. So all it takes is maybe a couple of phone calls from the union leaders to Nancy Pelosi's office, I guarantee they get on board.

CHAFFETZ: Donald Trump didn't become President Trump without those people swaying into his corner. They didn't believe where Hillary Clinton was on this. And even though it will give Donald Trump a victory, they have to go there and that's the President.

BARTIROMO: Richard Trumka joined us earlier in the week and just said exactly what you said, actually. That it was a good deal. And he really faced criticism from those outside the union.

So Krishna bottom line here, with all said, you're expecting this slowdown. Would you put your money to work in stocks?

MEMANI: Absolutely. Again, as I mentioned before, five more years. We expect the cycle to continue. There's still a lot of upside left in the market.

BARTIROMO: Even technology?

(CROSSTALK)

MEMANI: Especially in technology.

MURPHY: We need tech leadership. And I think you're going to see it in the last two months of the year.

BARTIROMO: We need tech leadership, why? Because that will confirm that this market is on firm footing.

MURPHY: Yes. But also because that's where the growth is.

BARTIROMO: Right.

MURPHY: So you need growth to have -- that's the strong leadership. Otherwise you have weak leadership which will eventually fail.

MEMANI: Those companies are actually executing fantastically. So I think tech is going to remain the leader.

CHAFFETZ: Is there any sector you don't like?

MEMANI: So I think the interest rate sensitive sectors is kind of in the walking around with an x on their back.

BARTIROMO: Like financials.

MEMANI: Financials, housing -- things like that, because the fed will continue to tighten for at least another six months. So I think there will be a time for that. But that's probably middle of next year rather than right now.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll leave it there. Krishna -- great to get your insights.

MEMANI: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much. Krishna Memani, Oppenheimer there.

Coming up, searching for a motive -- families are mourning this morning after 12 people were killed in a bar shooting in southern California yesterday. We have the very latest from southern California.

And then Speaker Pelosi once again -- Nancy Pelosi's renewed confidence in getting that gavel back.

All next, right here.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

New details emerging this morning about the mass shooting in California in that bar yesterday. Fox's Jonathan Hunt is in Thousand Oaks, California this morning with the very latest. Jonathan -- good morning.

JONATHAN HUNT, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Good morning to you -- Maria.

Hundreds of people turned out last night at a number of vigils to honor and remember the 12 people who were killed at the Borderline Bar and Grill, and to offer support to the victims' families.

Among those who died was a man whose mother says he survived the Las Vegas shooting massacre at a country music concert in October, 2017. Listen here to that distraught mother.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SUSAN SCHMIDT-ORFANOS, VICTIM'S MOTHER: My son was in Las Vegas with a lot of his friends and he came home. He didn't come home last night.

And I don't want prayers. I don't want thoughts. I want gun control. And I hope to God nobody else sends me anymore prayers. I want gun control. No more guns.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HUNT: Now, the gunman has been identified as 28-year-old Ian David Long, a U.S. Marine Corps veteran who served in Afghanistan.

We have obtained overnight disturbing video of the moments when he opened fire. Watch and listen here.

(VIDEO OF SHOOTING)

HUNT: He used a Glock-21 .45 caliber as his weapon of choice. It was legally bought, Maria, but it had an extended magazine, enabling him to fire more rounds. Those are illegal in California -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right. Jonathan -- thank you.

Jonathan Hunt in Thousand Oaks this morning.

We'll take a short break.

When we come back, three massive wildfires across California to tell you about. Several firefighters injured while battling these blazes. The latest coming up.

Then hey Alexa, give me Insight -- how author and advocate Deepak Chopra is teaming jp with Amazon to fill your morning routine with positive vibes. He's here in studio.

Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Insights and inspiration from world renowned Dr. Deepak Chopra in the palm of your hand -- thanks to a partnership between the Web site Live Person and Amazon's Alexa.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DR. DEEPAK CHOPRA, AUTHOR: I have this little microphone attached to this little phone. And I just speak out to what I'm thinking and what my intention for the day is. And then it's recorded here and it goes to Live Person and then it's on Alexa. It's all done very efficiently and smoothly and it's part of my daily routine now.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is the author of the brand-new book, "You are the Universe" and alternative medicine advocate, Deepak Chopra. Great to see you -- Deepak. Thanks for being here this morning.

CHOPRA: Thank you -- Maria.

BARTIROMO: Congratulations. Tell us about this new venture.

CHOPRA: Well, for the last 40 years I've been sharing my insights or reflections, meditations with people. It started with friends, then family, then social media, and now Alexa.

It wasn't planned but you know, I start my day with a few reflections and intentions -- a joyful, energetic body, love and compassion in the heart, clarity of mind, lightness of being. Then I expand on that and somehow Alexa picks it up to Live Person.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Tell us why that -- tell us why that's so important, the clarity that you try to have.

CHOPRA: I think setting an intention or even asking yourself a simple question like what do I want is enough. You don't have to actually concentrate on having a specific intention.

If you ask yourself, what do I want for me today or for the world or for my kids or -- you will already have a response there. That brings clarity to your intention. And if you start letting go and settle in your being, then that intention organizes its own fulfillment through synchronicity. That's a well-known spiritual tradition at least in the east.

BARTIROMO: And that organizes you to deal with sort of the chaos of the day or the noise of the day.

CHOPRA: Yes. The noise of the day. You carry your peace wherever you go, no matter what.

BARTIROMO: The technology is pretty user-friendly as well.

CHOPRA: I think the technology is going to be the next phase of our evolution for higher consciousness, if we want it. Technology can be destructive, as you know. Anything you can do with technology -- including hack the elections or whatever. But technology can also create a more peaceful, just, sustainable, healthier and joyful world.

BARTIROMO: So how does technology change going forward? What do you see that could be possible?

CHOPRA: What we see as the Internet -- that's our global brain right now. So if I send an abusive tweet, let's say to somebody in Africa, I could give them high blood pressure just by doing that.

On the other hand, I send them an emoticon with a hug, it could give them a dopamine hit. So, you know, technology is bringing together the collective brain. And the Internet is the human condition. If we don't like what's happening in the world we have to change that interconnectivity.

BARTIROMO: Is Live Person looking to recruit other celebrities to partake in AI-powered conversation?

CHOPRA: I think they are, yes. They're already looking at other people, influencers.

BARTIROMO: And maybe that will resonate with people to bring new people in.

CHOPRA: Yes. We need a critical mass of people who want a more peaceful, just, sustainable, healthier, and joyful world. That can only happen if we collectively have that intention and rewire our collective brain, which is the Internet. It's our brain.

BARTIROMO: Do you do new intentions every day?

CHOPRA: Yes.

BARTIROMO: How do those intentions come to you? Just depends on what you're looking for that day -- what do you want?

CHOPRA: I do a morning meditation which is always preceded by four questions. Who am I? What do I want? What's my purpose? And what am I grateful for? And then something comes up.

BARTIROMO: That will lead you to your intention. Very good.

Tell us about book, "You are the Universe", the main theme.

CHOPRA: It's about the fact that we live in a human universe. What you see outside here is a human creation. But what we don't realize is even things like stars, galaxies and our own bodies are human concepts around perceptual experiences.

In other words, the world is not out there. It's in you. Your body is in you. Your mind is in you. By you, I mean the infinite consciousness that modifies itself as perceptions, thoughts, feelings, emotions.

So any experience you have, doesn't matter what the experience. It's either a sensation or a perception or an image or a feeling or a thought. Once you understand that, you can go back through the source, through meditation as you're doing right now, then that opens the door to creativity, insight, intuition, imagination -- everything else.

BARTIROMO: Gives you that clarity that you're looking for.

CHOPRA: Right.

BARTIROMO: Deepak -- thanks very much.

CHOPRA: Thanks, Maria, for having me.

BARTIROMO: Great to talk with you as always.

CHOPRA: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Deepak Chopra.

Coming up, buying a home will cost you more. Mortgage rates are surging to the highest level in nearly a decade.

Plus the taste of Christmas this morning, this wine and cheese advent calendar is so popular it's fetching a hefty price on eBay. Wait until you see it. We've got it here.

Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Friday, November 9th. Your top stories right now, 7:30 a.m. on the East Coast.

Wall Street in the red this morning. Take a look, we're at the lows of the morning right here with the Dow Industrials set to open down about 140 points, that's one half of one percent lower. S&P is down two thirds of a percent and the NASDAQ with a 68 point decline, down almost one percent right now.

The Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged as expected yesterday. The markets were quiet. The major indices finished mostly flat on that news, up 11 points on the Dow, down seven on the S&P, down 40 points on the NASDAQ yesterday.

In Europe, the selling continues, down across the board, FT-100 down one percent, as is the CAC Quarante, DAX Index in Germany down two thirds of one percent.

Overnight in Asia, similar story, lower across the board, worst performer was Hong Kong, down 2-1/3 percent on the Hang Seng.

Oil has entered a bear market. The price of crude oil down 21 percent in just under a month. Oil now below $60.00 a barrel.

Meanwhile, Florida election turmoil, big story this morning, Governor Rick Scott asking for an investigation into voter fraud after accusing Democrats of trying to steal the midterm election.

Fast moving wildfires in California to report, two firefighters are injured battling three blazes. Look at that. Plus, thousands of residents fleeing for their lives including Kim Kardashian, among others.

Mortgage mess, home sales slowing down, mortgage rates surging to the highest level in nearly a decade. We've got the details on how much it is costing now.

And then, cheers to you, all these wine Advent calendars sold out fast. You can still find one, we've got it here, it may cost you a pretty penny, though. We're going to tell you all about it coming up.

But first our top story this half an hour, the battle for the gavel, House Minority leader Nancy Pelosi officially launching her bid for House speakership. And in an interview last night, she weighed in on her chances.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CHRIS CUOMO, ANCHOR, CNN: What is your level of confidence that you'll be the speaker of the House?

SEN. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA), SENATE MINORITY LEADER: total.

CUOMO: 100 percent?

PELOSI: 100 percent.

CUOMO: Do you have any reservations about whether or not you want this in your life at this point?

PELOSI: No, none, whatsoever. I've had -- it's an urgency that I can't resist.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining us right now is The Weekly Standard deputy editor Kelly Jane Torrance. Kelly Jane, good to see you this morning. Is she a shoe-in for this?

KELLY JANE TORRANCE, DEPUTY EDITOR, THE WEEKLY STANDARD: No, she is not, Maria. And you know, her confidence is impressive. You know, we talk a lot about big egos here in Washington and we always talk about men. But let's face it; women can have big egos too. And I think -- you know, very few in Washington have them as big as Nancy Pelosi.

You know, so they -- a bunch of -- about a dozen Democrats who do not want to see her as speaker. Again, actually, organized a call last night, trying to figure out how they can stop her. One of them was Conor Lamb of Pennsylvania who of course is -- you know, a moderate Democrat, recently ran and won his seat. Another was Tim Ryan of Ohio who actually had run against Pelosi in the past. He says he doesn't want to run this time but he's trying to find someone, anyone who will. And that might be actually the biggest problem for the Pelosi opponents is there doesn't seem to be a candidate that people are sort of getting behind and interested in.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

TORRANCE: And no one's -- no one's declared they want to run. And of course, I don't blame them because who wants to get on Nancy Pelosi's bad side.

BARTIROMO: Right. Well, they don't want to run but they don't want her to run. In fact, Tim Ryan joined me on Sunday, Congressman from Ohio, and I asked him if he's going to challenge her. I think he's actually more interested in challenging President Trump in 2020 but he did say he is not voting for Pelosi. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: After the 2016 election you wanted to unseat Nancy Pelosi to become speaker of the House. Are you running for Speaker of the House this time?

REP. TIM RYAN (D), OHIO: We got a couple more days. There are a number of candidates that are having conversations that are talking about running. I will say it's not going to be a coronation. Somebody is going to run for leadership. I think it's important that we have this discussion and have this conversation. I think the American people want a change. I think a lot of Democrats want a change.

BARTIROMO: Right.

RYAN: And so, we're going to have that discussion starting on Wednesday and let's hope we're having a conversation about speaker of the House and not leader of the minority party in Congress. But there's a lot of conversations happening right now.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And Jason Chaffetz is here, Kelly Jane. And you (INAUDIBLE) from the beginning, you don't think she has the votes.

JASON CHAFFETZ, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Well, there's too many people that were on the record and remember, the very first vote that you cast as a member of Congress is who's going to be the next speaker. And you're going to ask these people like Lamb out of Pennsylvania to take that tough vote. So, I don't know how she gets to 218. But you're right, she certainly is confident.

But Kelly, I want to ask you, has leader McCarthy signaled what's going to happen in the next seven weeks? I mean, the Republicans are still in control in the House and Senate and the presidency for the next seven weeks. Have we seen what that agenda is going to be?

TORRANCE: No, we -- you know what, I've heard very little coming through. And you know, even Republicans are calling it a lame duck session, which you know, you think, you've got your last chance to do something and they don't seem very interested in taking it. I think they're a little more preoccupied and worried about what's going to come next.

Now, of course one of the things that Donald Trump has talked about upcoming in the House is the speaker run and he's of course tweeted that he really thinks the Democrats should have Nancy Pelosi. And I don't think that has helped her cause.

But you know, as you -- as you -- you know, it was funny because you had Tim Ryan on and talked about, Maria, you said he might want to run against President Trump. Well, he actually brought up Trump and Pelosi in the same sentence this week after the elections, saying that, pointing out that exit polls showed that Nancy Pelosi's negatives were on par with Trump's at 55 percent, he said. So, he's definitely trying to tie those two together. And we'll see how successful he is. But I mean, Jason, do you think there's anyone who's really ready to step up and challenge her?

CHAFFETZ: I -- there's got to be somebody, somebody in that leadership team will actually change. And I think between the congressional black caucus, the Hispanic caucus. I think Lujan has a -- has a great case to make that he helped bring them back into power. In fact, that California and New York have so many members is going to be a problematic. But you basically see Democrats on the coast. You don't hear much about a Tim Ryan because there aren't as many Democrats in the middle part of the country and they certainly haven't gotten organized.

BARTIROMO: Yes and there's this fight, right, within the Democratic Party since they've gone lurching all the way to the left. And that's one of the issues.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes.

BARTIROMO: But we've got to get to the Florida Senate race. Because this is also one of the top stories. We've got to get your take on this situation, getting even tighter. Republican candidate Rick Scott filing explosive lawsuit against top election officials in two heavily Democratic counties. He detailed the allegations at a news conference yesterday. Watch this Kelly Jane.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GOV. RICK SCOTT (R-FL), SENATORIAL CANDIDATE: I will not sit idly by why unethical liberals try to steal this election. Their goal is to keep mysteriously finding more votes until the elections turn out the way they want.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And the same in Arizona Kelly Jane, your reaction?

TORRANCE: Yes, you know, I have to say, you know, Bill Nelson is trying to claim that -- you know, this is a politically motivated action by Rick Scott, by -- you know, getting law enforcement to investigate. Well, what's wrong with an investigation? What do you have to worry about? I thought Democrats were all in favor of investigations to find out the truth. And let's face it, Broward county, you know, Miami-Dade, recounts, we've heard about this before haven't we?

BARTIROMO: Yes, we have.

TORRANCE: And these are -- you know, heavily Democratic districts. And when you have suddenly votes being tallied and very quickly the margin changing from one where there wasn't going to be a recount to close enough where there were not only be a machine recount, there'd be a hand recount. You do have to worry about that.

Now, the deadline is Saturday noon for them to -- for the counties to file the election results. So, Rick Scott was in court. He's trying to get emergency hearings. So something can happen because of course, once you get that hand recount, again, these officials, it's a very heavily Democratic area and I don't blame him for being nervous. And you know, Arizona too, we saw very quickly all of a sudden margins changing, you know, within an hour we had -- you know, almost a percentage point I think.

So yes, you know, it's very nerve-racking. Especially with the Republicans, no matter what happens in these two races, looks like Republicans are going to hold the Senate.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

TORRANCE: But of course, those margins matter a lot as we saw over the last year.

CHAFFETZ: Look, there were tens of thousands of votes difference going into this race in the previous recounts or previous times it was less than a thousand votes. So, there -- it really does something -- seem to be something suspicious here. And I think it was actually Senator Marco Rubio that was really pointing it out earlier in the day yesterday, if you go back and look at his tweets and what he was saying about the shenanigans that have been happening there in Florida. But you also have these allegations about how some of the counties in Arizona have been counting this too. And there is obviously a lot on the line.

MIKE MURPHY, MANAGING PARTNER & CEO, ROSECLIFF: And you know, it's crazy to me that we've talked so much about Russian meddling in our elections and now we don't need Russia, we're meddling in our own elections here. I mean, there have -- we have to use technology to make this voting process.

MCDOWELL: Well, now there are accusations of racism in Florida and Georgia and that's why Andrew Gillum and Stacey Abrams didn't win. Let me just point out that President Barack Obama won Florida two times and John James in Michigan lost. So is that racism?

CHAFFETZ: It is interesting in Arizona because Governor Ducey was reelected by a very large margin. And the number of people that would have to take to vote for Ducey and then switch parties to vote for Krysten Sinema, that's a fascinating number. It doesn't seem to make a lot of sense.

BARTIROMO: It was incredible how close Sinema. I mean, now Sinema is in the lead.

MCDOWELL: Right, he was campaign -- Doug Ducey was campaigning a lot with Martha McSally to at the very end. Trying to pull her across the line with him.

CHAFFETZ: But who goes to the poll and votes Ducey, Sinema? That doesn't make a lot of sense.

BARTIROMO: No, it doesn't. And what about this, Michelle Obama ripping President Trump in her new book Becoming. She writes about the shock that she felt on election night when she learned that President Trump would succeed her husband, saying that she tries to, quote, block it all out. Kelly Jane, your reaction?

TORRANCE: You know, I'm trying not to laugh too hard. Block it all out. Well, you know, yes, she's upset that someone that replaced her husband is dismantling some of his legacy, and I sort of hate to use the word legacy because it hasn't been positive. I mean, look at how much the economy has gotten better since then.

And I -- you know, look at Iran. I mean, you had a president who is you know, sucking up to people who murder their own people for speaking out against the government and now we have someone who's standing with the people of Iran. So, yes, she has a right to be upset a little bit, I guess. But is this all -- is this book just a ploy? Is she going to run? What's the point of the book otherwise, right? It has to make a lot of money which you know, politicians like to do.

MCDOWELL: I just want to add really quickly, you can look at the expression on Michelle Obama's face, the first lady's face on Inauguration Day. She was sick of Washington and it had nothing to do with right versus left, Republican versus Democrat.

BARTIROMO: Right.

MCDOWELL: I think she just wanted out of the political circles of D.C. I'll just throw that in there.

BARTIROMO: Those were right, it's true, yes. Kelly Jane, go ahead. Final word.

TORRANCE: I was going to say, you know what, Dagen, great point, although, I think she likes to still be in the arena. I mean, she's made so many comments since then. I think, you know, she didn't like being in the -- you know, the everyday life, political life of D.C. But she likes to talk a lot of the big picture.

BARTIROMO: Well, she wrote a book.

TORRANCE: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: She wrote a book, Becoming. Kelly Jane Torrance, good to see you. Thank you so much. We will see you soon.

TORRANCE: Thank you, have a great weekend.

BARTIROMO: And to you. Coming up, we've got a trio of wildfires burning across California, incredible pictures, injuring two firefighters. Take a look, the blazes forced thousands of people from their homes including Kim Kardashian among others. We're going to tell you her story when we come back.

And then, mortgage rates are surging to the highest level in nearly 10 years. It is taking a toll on the housing market. We'll tell you about it, next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Three major wildfires burning out of control right now in California. Cheryl Casone with the headlines, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, this is a fast-moving fire, Maria. It's forced evacuations in northern California. The camp fire has burned about 18,000 acres, destroying a number of structures, at least two firefighters and multiple civilians have been injured so far.

And then we're learning now that Kim Kardashian-West says that she was also forced to leave her home in the town of Hidden Hills. This happened last night, because of that fire. So she share this image on her Instagram said, in part I pray everyone is safe. But what's interesting is that she was taking those pictures out of her jet as she was coming home Maria, only to land and find out her own home was actually in danger.

So meanwhile, let's look at Southern California. Two wildfires have also triggered evacuations in Ventura County. The National Weather Service has issued red flag warnings throughout much of the state. Well, hopefully this fire gets under control today when the sun comes up in the California.

Another headline we're following, the cost of financing the purchase of a new home heading higher. The average rate on a 30 year fixed rate mortgage jumped to 4.94 percent, that's the highest level in nearly eight years. Higher rates are -- priced many prospective home buyers out of the market. Existing home sales have fallen for the past six months. Rates are climbing of course, as the Fed is raising borrowing costs. They don't want the economy to overheat. But your mortgage might be a little more expensive.

All right, then there is this, Aldi's first ever wine Advent calendar may be sold out in stores but you can still get your hands on one. But it's going to frankly cost you a lot. The (INAUDIBLE) calendar, it's got 24 mini bottles of wine guys for $70.00. But now we're seeing it on eBay, huge markup, one just sold for $300, Maria. Plus $50.00 in shipping because it's super heavy as we just found out on our set as we tried to pick it up. It's 21 pounds. It's a wine calendar, it's got cheeses in it. And they're not going to restock it. So we got one on set but we can't open it because it's a hot property.

CHAFFETZ: We can open the cheese.

(CROSSTALK)

CASONE: Well, OK.

CHAFFETZ: I don't drink alcohol but (INAUDIBLE) I'll get the cheese.

BARTIROMO: OK, let's see you open it.

MCDOWELL: No, why can't we open it though? I mean, I'm not talking about drinking it.

BARTIROMO: Yes, let's open it and look at it.

CASONE: This is supposedly hot property. I know. So, here's how this works.

BARTIROMO: Take the cheese out, OK.

CASONE: So, there's little mini bottles. Well, I'm just going to do it. If I get in trouble, well, I'll pay for it. All right, so, there's like one -- you know, 20 to 30 is the different day.

MCDOWELL: I want to know how mini -- I want to know how mini these bottles are.

BARTIROMO: I love it.

MCDOWELL: Because if it's only like a glass per bottle.

CASONE: Look at that.

BARTIROMO: Ok, so this is number --

CASONE: Well then, that's not bad if it's a mini bottle. Jason, you may have to help me open this. I can't get these open.

MURPHY: The one issue is that with the Advent calendar I like to do it in the morning. Like, kind of tough to open the wine and that could create a problem if you drinking the wine in the morning.

CASONE: All right, I can't get this open. People are telling me to --

BARTIROMO: Jason (INAUDIBLE)

CASONE: Will you help me open it.

CHAFFETZ: I'm all about the cheese.

BARTIROMO: He's all about the cheese.

CASONE: I got the -- I'm trying to get the wine open. Can we just take a commercial break? (INAUDIBLE) not to open the wine is kind of a shock.

CHAFFETZ: Hang this on the wall and say kids, go get a piece of cheese.

BARTIROMO: It's like a gift.

CASONE: If you pay the $300 guys, not to self, get a knife or something to open it. But there's little mini bottles of wine and it's all different like Rose and Soras and Merlot and Cabs and all kinds of fun stuff, it's fun.

MURPHY: Great for the holidays.

BARTIROMO: And I love the Advent calendar.

CHAFFETZ: I have the Gouda.

MCDOWELL: It better be more than a glass a bottle.

CASONE: They're baby bottles. So, yes.

MCDOWELL: Baby bottles (INAUDIBLE)

BARTIROMO: All right, thank you Cheryl.

CASONE: I'm going to work on this, I'm not leaving.

BARTIROMO: Coming up, honoring veterans in style. We're going to show you more of these crafts created by a pair of sisters who also support veterans through every stage of their business. Wait until you see this. Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Support veterans and honor them every day, that is the mission behind the company Sword and Plough. And we like that mission right here on MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Joining me right now are the sisters behind the company, CEO and former U.S. Army Captain Emily Nunez is here -- Emily Nunez Cavness along with co-founder and chief operating officer Betsy Nunez. Great to see you girls. Thank you so much for joining us.

BETSY NUNEZ, CO-FOUNDER AND CHIEF OPERATING OFFICER, SWORD AND PLOUGH: Thank you for having us, Maria.

EMILY NUNEZ-CAVNESS, CEO, SWORD AND PLOUGH: Great to see you.

BARTIROMO: I'm just -- you know, you just get me -- I mean, I'm in awe knowing that you are in Kandahar Afghanistan, what you've done, your father is one of the great vets as well. Thank you for your service.

NUNEZ: Thank you so much. We are just thrilled to be here, especially right before Veterans Day which is incredibly important to Sword and Plough our mission.

BARTIROMO: Why is the company called Sword and Plough?

CAVNESS: So, it comes from the phrase to turns swords into ploughshares, which means to take a military technology and apply it to a peaceful civilian application. And that's really exactly what we're doing with our made in America products and repurposing thousands and thousands of military surplus into all of our designs.

BARTIROMO: I love this. And the last time you came you had lots of camo products. Now, you have little camo and tell me about what the products are this time.

CAVNESS: Sure, so we've got an assortment. We have everything from jewelry, necklaces, earrings made out of repurposed bullet casing, 50 caliber shell casing.

BARTIROMO: Nice. My goodness, you're kidding.

CAVNESS: Hand-hammered by an incredible female vet in Kentucky named Shana. And then we've got assortment of everything from bags to travel kits, essentially anything for you, a family member, loved one and they make perfect gifts for the holiday.

BARTIROMO: What's the best selling item?

NUNEZ: Our best sellers are definitely our necklaces. They're just so one of a kind. They don't look anything like what they're made out of. This big 50 caliber shell casing, and so, that's been a big hit.

BARTIROMO: So, tell me how that's done with the casing?

NUNEZ: Sure, this amazing veteran named Shana is in Kentucky, and she actually hand hammers every single bullet casing into this beautiful pieces of jewelry. And she actually was a 50 caliber machine gunner when she was in the Army and when she was deployed in Afghanistan. So, it's an amazing full circle -- full circle experience.

BARTIROMO: It is incredible.

CAVNESS: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Tell us about the events you have on top this month.

CAVNESS: Yes, so, we're gearing up for Veterans Day, obviously, big this Sunday, and then gearing up for holiday season. But today, we're donating 10 percent of profits from any of the sales on our website SwordandPlough.com to bumper labs. And they do incredible work. They are helping veterans and military spouses start their own business. So the sale of our products and the production of our products helps support veteran employment and empowerment at every stage in our business. And for your viewers we have a special code, FOX10, for 10 percent off for today through the weekend.

BARTIROMO: Thank you for that discount for our viewers.

CAVNESS: Of course.

BARTIROMO: And not only that, but it's real quality.

NUNEZ: Thank you, they last forever.

BARTIROMO: They last forever.

NUNEZ: We also have a steadfast guarantee. So if anything should ever happen, we repair it free of cost.

BARTIROMO: Give me the average prices here.

CAVNESS: Sure, we've got everything from $19.00 to $350, we do free shipping on all orders $200 and up. And everything from tote bag that makes a great diaper bag or bag for work to a cosmetic case or a toiletry case if you're traveling or if your husband needs an upgrade for the -- for the bathroom sink.

BARTIROMO: Very cool. Emily and Betsy, great to see you again. Thanks so much.

NUNEZ: Thank you -- thank you so much, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Happy Veterans Day to you both and to your father. Emily Nunez-Cavness and Betsy Nunez. Back in a minute.
